text: I've written about this a lot for PathFactory. My short answer is both, but it also depends on your tech stack.

elements.text: I've written about this a lot for PathFactory. My short answer is both, but it also depends on your tech stack.

text: In our own marketing, we use optional/soft and engagement-based forms to identify unknown visitors only. Known visitors never see forms on content.

elements.text: In our own marketing, we use optional/soft and engagement-based forms to identify unknown visitors only. Known visitors never see forms on content.

text: If we were playing marry/kill for gated/ungated, i'd say ungated. for the SEO juice, for the frictionlessness, for the other benefits that don't necessarily involve growing your database. (like you would with gated)

elements.text: If we were playing marry/kill for gated/ungated, i'd say ungated. for the SEO juice, for the frictionlessness, for the other benefits that don't necessarily involve growing your database. (like you would with gated)

text: but gated does play a role in the whole content marketing ecosystem. this is just if i had to choose between the two hypothetically. lol

text: This is our only gated content. I think the question of *Could I charge for this information?* helps when deciding whether to gate something. <https://dispatch.m.io/mio-workplace-messaging-report/>

attachments.title: Workplace Messaging Report - Slack, Microsoft Teams & Webex Teams
attachments.text: As the Skype for Business end of life date is announced, find out which app IT Managers said they were most likely to move to next.
attachments.fallback: Workplace Messaging Report - Slack, Microsoft Teams & Webex Teams

elements.text: This is our only gated content. I think the question of
Could I charge for this information?
helps when deciding whether to gate something.

text: I'd say only gate research

elements.text: I'd say only gate research

text: I think it depends on the amount of leads and sales being made. If your machine is running optimally then offer everything for free, if you're struggling with leads and need more prospects create content that will allow you to capture info in a helpful and genuine way.

elements.text: I think it depends on the amount of leads and sales being made. If your machine is running optimally then offer everything for free, if you're struggling with leads and need more prospects create content that will allow you to capture info in a helpful and genuine way.

text: <@UJJFDTN8G> Lolll and it gets worse because it was for a selfish reason - i have to defend "ungated" in a debate in front of the rest of my team

elements.text: Lolll and it gets worse because it was for a selfish reason - i have to defend "ungated" in a debate in front of the rest of my team

text: I don't think we marketers are very good judges about what we could and could not charge for when it comes to content.

elements.text: I don't think we marketers are very good judges about what we could and could not charge for when it comes to content.

text: I think we'd all be very surprised if we turned our websites into eCommerce websites and asked for money in exchange for content.

elements.text: I think we'd all be very surprised if we turned our websites into eCommerce websites and asked for money in exchange for content.

text: The point of content is to educate your prospects and customers so they build a relationship with your brand and, hopefully, eventually, feel educated enough to buy something from you. Forms are in direct conflict with that goal.

elements.text: The point of content is to educate your prospects and customers so they build a relationship with your brand and, hopefully, eventually, feel educated enough to buy something from you. Forms are in direct conflict with that goal.

text: This is hard to quantify, but I feel pretty strongly that B2B brands, in particular, have gone a little crazy on the gating. It's starting to feel like everybody's holding their best stuff hostage for email addresses, which for my money feels extractive and betrays a lack of confidence in the ability of your content to close the deal otherwise.

elements.text: This is hard to quantify, but I feel pretty strongly that B2B brands, in particular, have gone a little crazy on the gating. It's starting to feel like everybody's holding their best stuff hostage for email addresses, which for my money feels extractive and betrays a lack of confidence in the ability of your content to close the deal otherwise.

text: that's not to say "never gate". But more like:  only gate the *really* juicy stuff. Pretty much only OG research. and NEVER case studies.

elements.text: that's not to say "never gate". But more like:  only gate the
really
juicy stuff. Pretty much only OG research. and NEVER case studies.

text: Yup - I really hesitate to put any hard numbers around it, butttt if I had to make a general estimate, I wouldn't make more than 10% of a brand's content gated. My rule of thumb is 1 piece of gated content for every main persona, maybe 1 for each persona per use case for bigger cos.

text:
Does anyone else work receive a high volume of requests from various employee groups for content support, which is sometimes but not always marketing-related (eg employer brand)?

I’m wondering how you educate non-marketers internally on whether these ideas fit into your strategy, are something your team can support, etc. More in thread.

elements.text: Does anyone else work receive a high volume of requests from various employee groups for content support, which is sometimes but not always marketing-related (eg employer brand)?
I’m wondering how you educate non-marketers internally on whether these ideas fit into your strategy, are something your team can support, etc. More in thread.

text:
We have some phenomenal and very engaged employee resource groups who have a ton of ideas for blog posts, a podcast, case studies etc...but most are coming from employees who don’t usually work on these types of initiatives and aren’t familiar with our strategy or the work some of these require to produce. We’re hearing about them after their plans and our strategic priorities for both marketing and employer brand have already been finalized. 

Would love advice from others who’ve managed these conversations, in particular if you’ve had success creating a solid planning process with employee groups or employee initiatives outside of marketing and sales (we do work with our people team on EB but these initiatives are all led by different individuals outside of that team).

elements.text: We have some phenomenal and very engaged employee resource groups who have a ton of ideas for blog posts, a podcast, case studies etc...but most are coming from employees who don’t usually work on these types of initiatives and aren’t familiar with our strategy or the work some of these require to produce. We’re hearing about them after their plans and our strategic priorities for both marketing and employer brand have already been finalized.

Would love advice from others who’ve managed these conversations, in particular if you’ve had success creating a solid planning process with employee groups or employee initiatives outside of marketing and sales (we do work with our people team on EB but these initiatives are all led by different individuals outside of that team).

text: No worries. This is still pretty interesting. How did you collect all your survey data anyhow? Was it in this group or elsewhere? I'm looking to do something similar for ecommerce.
